title: covid-scotland-vaccine-passport
story: Jason Leitch, the countrys national clinical director, said the passports are an "interesting concept".But what are the passports, and how would they work in Scotland A vaccine passport is an internationally recognised travel pass which would prove whether or not people have had a Covid vaccine.It could,implemented, allow people to prove their status and potentially travel abroad.It is being pushed forward by former prime minister Tony Blair, who told Boris Johnson thatBritain should use itspresidency of the G to launch theldquointernational Covid Pass.It is far too early to say, however Mr Blair says he believes the passport scheme should consist of a single, standardised digital system. He says it should be capable of tracking and verying an iniduals vaccine status across the world.It could, according to Blair, involve not only how many vaccinations someone has had , but also any test results they may have had in the past.It is hoped that the data would be transferred using a QR code, which would be scanned by participating countries at borders and ports.In evidence to the Scottish Parliamentrsquos Covid- Committee on Thursday, Professor Leitch said coronavirus is likely to be present in some sort of ldquoendemic form for years to come.When he was asked about vaccine passports, hesaid: ldquoI agree it is an interesting concept, the WHOhave begun to look at it.He stressed the latest scientic evidence suggests vaccination is not a ldquobinary state, but there is precedent for travel restrictions based on vaccination ndash including yellow fever certicates.Prof Leitch said: ldquoI think we will probably move towards that. I havenrsquot seen the exact details of what Mr Blairrsquos think tank have said but I imagine itrsquos relatively sensible, itrsquos about doing it globally rather than just an inidual region of the world.Zurab Pololikashvili, the UN World Tourism Organisationrsquos secretary-general, last week told the Global Tourism Crisis Committee in Madrid: ldquoVaccines must be part of a wider, coordinated approach that includes certicates and passes for safe cross-border travel.The leaders of Spain, Italy, Greece, Cyprus and Malta have called for the introduction of certicates which designatea traveller has been vaccinated or not.On Monday, Australiarsquos education minister, Alan Tudge, said planned ldquodigital vaccine certicates would allow international students toto study in the country without the need for them to hotel quarantine.The head of the UKrsquos data privacy watchdog has told MPs she can see the benefit of Covid- immunity passports, but warned they came with privacy concerns.Information commissioner Elizabeth Denham was asked by MPs on the Digital, Culture, Media and Sportsub-committee on Online Harms and Disinformation about the possible use of special passports to allow those who had been vaccinated to move more freely.She said any such scheme would face substantial questions over its necessity and concerns over the sharing of health data, but warned of creating a ldquotwo-tier system where people who have received a vaccine have more freedoms than those who have not.

title: kinghorn-sharon-small-loves-fife-town
story: Where is it Kinghorn, Fe. Hitting the beach and going for a walk at Pettycur with the view to the Forth Bridges.As a teenager, I wanted to get away from it because it seemed so small at the time. It is a place where all my angst and aspirations were happening, looking out at that skyline and across to Edinburgh.I used to ask the Inchkeith lighthouse questions andthe light came round on the full light, it meant yes ndash it was almost like a Magic  Ball.We moved from Clydebank when I was  ndash this was  ndash and hit the east coast. It was totally dferent. But now I have come to appreciate how beautul it is and what a great thing to have in my le, that much sky, the sea air and freedom.I have been away since  but I can go back to Kinghorn and people will be like: "You alright, Sharon  Hows it going " They dont forget you.:Author Catriona McPherson on the joys of GallowayIm bringing children up in the city. Although we are in north London and have green space, it is a dferent mindset bringing kids up today. There is a lot less freedom. As kids, we played in fields and would go off in the morning and didnt come back until we were starving. Now it is play-by-appointment.Why do you go there My mammy is there. She is the hub for our family. Im the eldest of five and these days we are scattered around the country in Glasgow, Dunfermline, Glenrothes and two of us down in London.How often do you go Usually, a couple of times each year. Last summer, when the travel restrictions eased, we stayed in a caravan at Pettycur. My mum has been unwell, and we needed to go see her. We went in July and had the amazing view out to Pettycur Beach.Sharon Small as Rose Marshbrook in series two of ITV drama The Bay. Picture: Ben Blackall copyTall Story Pictures  ITVWhats your favourite memory Regatta days when it was sunny, the sea was blue and all that lovely peach light. Seeing the sailing boats going up and down, I always used to feel energised by that.Growing up, we played a lot of street games. Where my mum lives, the cul-de-sac is full of cars now, whereas when I was younger, there were very few people who had or could afford cars. We had the run of the whole scheme and would play games like Bulldog and Chainy.Who do you take My partner Dan and our two boys. I like to go back to Kinghorn and remember that angsty teenager and, in a way, take some peace from it because there are a lot of sacrices when you move away from home. I think: "This is beautul to come back to but Im glad I made the decisions I did."What do you take Waterproofs. You have to be prepared for four seasons in one day.What do you leave behind The London mindset and anonymity. In Scotland, people are more engaged.:Crime writer Quintin Jardine on his enduring love for a little corner of CataloniaSum it up in a few words.The Bridges. Peach light. Wellbeing. Aspirations. Wet and windy.What travel spot is on your post-lockdown wish list For total relaxation and emptying my head, the Males. It was there that Dan and I decided, early in our relationship, that we are good together. I would love to go back with the kids.We have been talking as a family about doing some city breaks. The boys are  and  and havent been interested in city breaks before. We have always done the classic villa or a caravan in Scotland. Florence is on our list and I also have a real hankering to visit Vienna.Sharon Small stars in The Bay on STV, Wednesdays, pm

title: mary-continis-home-cooking-recipe-roasted-lamb-chops-fennel-lemon
story: In Rome, at Easter, very young lamb is served on all restaurant menus. It is spectacularly delicious.It goes without saying that Scottish lamb is the best. The spring lamb, typically less than three months old, will not reach our butcher shops for a few months yet. The lamb on sale now will be older, - months old, with fuller, richer flavour. It is not yet classed as mutton, which is older yet, sold up to  years old and has a far more gamey, stronger flavour.The lamb we buy now benefits from longer slow cooking with fuller flavours added to complement its taste. It is perfect for stews and curries, but I like this slow roasting recipe which makes for a rich, satisfying meal.Roasted lamb chops with fennel and lemonPre-heat oven gas c gas  single loin lamb chops cloves garlic sprigs fresh rosemaryExtra virgin olive oil- floury potatoes, Maris Piper, Desiree red onion bulb fennel teaspoon fennel seedsZest and juice of  unwaxed lemonml dry white wineSea salt and black pepperStud the chops with a few slithers of garlic and season them well. Drizzle with olive oil.Peel the potatoes and cut into - cm pieces. Put the potatoes in a bowl with - tablespoons of olive oil, season with salt and pepper and toss them in the oil so that they are well coated.Cut the onion into eighths, you can leave the skin on.Remove the core and tough outer leaves from the fennel bulb and cut into rough pieces, keeping aside the fennel fronds to decorate later.Throw everything into a heavy bottomed roasting tin and scatter with a teaspoon or so of fennel seeds.Add the zest and juice of an unwaxed lemon.Use your hands to toss everything together so that everything is well coated with the oil.Roast in the oven for  minutes.Check the roasting tray and turn everything around so that all sides of the lamb and potatoes get well roasted.Splash the white wine across everything and finish roasting for another - minutes or so.Serve all together, decorated with the fennel fronds.The roast fennel and red onion add a delicious jam-like accompaniment that adds to the flavour of the lamb and the crispy potatoes speak for themselves.

title: adrian-dunbars-coastal-ireland
story: Adrian Dunbars Coastal Ireland.Tell me more.The Line of Duty star is reconnecting with his roots as he explores the fascinating nooks and crannies of Irelands rugged and wild coastline.Mother of God!Was that a Line of Duty reference  Ill let it slide. title: lochaber-taste-highland-scotland-winter-glory
story: Grade: Moderately serious mountain walkDistance:  miles kmTime: - hoursITrsquoS ironic that within a couple of miles of one of Scotlandrsquos finest mountain footpaths lies one of the worst. The good path runs up the steep, airy edge of Gleouraichrsquos south-west ridge above Loch Quoich near Glengarry, a superb stalkersrsquo path that has been well maintained by the estate. But close by, at the eastern end of Loch Quoich, just south of its dam, another path leads to the Druim na Geid Salaich, a long, rising ridge that in turn gives access to the Munro of Gairich.The boggy, rutted, poorly drained and badly eroded nature of this path shouldnrsquot really surprise anyone for this is a land notorious for its high rainfall. The area around Loch Quoich, just west of Glen Garry, has the distinction of being one of the wettest places in Scotland.The area enjoys a real wilderness feel, despite the presence of a single-track road that runs along the north shore of the loch between Glen Garry and Kinloch Hourn.For all its wetness, the Loch Quoich area, and its Munros, remains a great favourite amongst hill bashers.Gairichstands in splendid isolation on the south side of the loch, gazing across the neck of water towards the Glengarry twins of Gleouraich and Spidean Mialach. A little way along the road north of the loch lies another magnicent Munro, Sgurr arsquo Mhaoraich.Irsquove often driven along this road and thought that the finest way to climb Gairich would be to canoe across the loch and climb the hill by its broad north ridge. You could then canoe back across the loch and add Sgurr arsquo Mhaoraich to your dayrsquos tally.This time, given the shorter hours of daylight, I was content with one Munro. After weeks of rain and wind, the Celtic winter god Biera got her act together, flourished her icicle wand and enveloped much of the Highlands in a smattering of snow and icy temperatures. This would be a good time to tackle Gairich, and I was hopeful her horrendously boggy approaches would form a deep-frozen highway.A pale sun shone from a milky, creamy sky as I set out but despite the low temperatures underfoot conditions were not ideal ndash as the rainwater that had previously flooded the path had turned to ice. I might have been better with ice skates so I left the slippery path after a kilometre or so, and took a more direct route, over crisp, crunchy frozen turf, onto the Druim na Geid Salaich.Once I reached the crest of the ridge overhead conditions dramatically improved too. Great streaks of blue sky appeared through the high cloud and the sun broke through ndash the first Irsquod seen in weeks. Away ahead of me I could see other climbers on the sharply defined east ridge of Gairich and beyond lay the jumbled hills of Knoydart.As the ridge widens out onto the Bac nam Foid it usually becomes increasingly boggy and cut up by peat hags, but a couple of inches of fresh snow lay on top of old neacuteveacute, hard snow that has frozen and thawed several times, and it was delight to walk on it. Soon I was climbing up through rocky outcrops and crags, avoiding the icy sections as much as possible.Various tracks cross the south-east slopes of this hill and itrsquos easy to follow them too far west, but by keeping on a rising traverse as close to the crest as possible I managed to pick a line through the dficulties to the surprisingly broad summit ridge and cairn.The cold was intense but the views were magnicent, the white crests of the hills rising from russet flanks. I could see the Cuillin of Skye, I could see Ben Nevis crouching over its acolytes but best of all were the Knoydart hills, wild Scotland in all her winter glory.Cameron McNeishROUTE PLANNERMap: OS :, Landranger sheet  Distance:  miles lkmApprox Time: - hoursStart Finish: Loch Quoich dam .Route: From S end of dam a path leads to an old stalkersrsquo path that runs S over boggy moors to the edge of a forestry plantation. Here, another path runs due W up the Druim na Geid Salaich. Once the broad ridge crest is reached the path peters out but the going is easy and the broad ridge should be followed W to the final steep pull to Gairich. At the foot of this final rise a path reappears, but after a while it runs out on to the S face. Donrsquot be tempted by it but continue climbing on the ridge crest to the spacious summit and large cairn. Return the same way.Due to current restrictions, we are running our favourite previously published walks. Please follow the Scottish Governmentrsquos latest coronavirus restrictions, see https:www.gov. scot coronaviruscovid-

title: anyone-feel-living-groundhog-day
story: "Ah, but will February be any better " I hear you ask. "We are still lumbering on in lockdown limbo." You make a good point. However, February does have Shrove Tuesday. As much as I enjoy a big plate of haggis, neeps and tatties on Burns Night, I relish a towering stack of pancakes even more.My mother is a dab hand at making pancakes. I have a supply in the freezer, ready to be thawed and slathered in maple syrup, whipped cream, bananas and ice cream .:Susan Swarbricks Week: I definitely need to find a new hobbyThis year Shrove Tuesday falls on February . Two days after Valentines Day. Which is a greenlight for a run of indulgence, no matter how you see it. Although the less said about Valentines Day, the better. Im a sucker for romance but the rampant commercialisation sticks in the craw.Ash Wednesday on February  marks the beginning of Lent. Now, as much as I respect the religious importance, surely this year we should see some form of Lent Lite Anyone who has the necessary willpower, resilience and tenacity to last  days in a pandemic without indulgences ndash or staples as I now like to think of them ndash is a shoo-in candidate for the Mars mission.First, though, we have Groundhog Day this Tuesday, observed in the US and Canada each February  in honour of a marmot meteorologist called Punxsutawney Phil.Bill Murray in the  film Groundhog DayThe bizarre ritual marks the midpoint between the winter solstice and the spring equinox. According to legend,the groundhog emerges from his burrow and sees a shadow, winter will last six more weeks. If not, then expect an early spring.Sky Cinema will be doing its annual tradition of marking Groundhog Day with back-to-back screenings of the  film about a pompous weather reporter made to live the same day on a loop until he mends the errors of his ways.Deja vu  It feels like we are caught in the Groundhog Day of Prime Minister Boris Johnson, one where we must endure watching him repeating the same excruciating mistakes over and over.I have spent much of the past week trying to wrap my head around that figure of , deaths in the UK from coronavirus. A number so immense and unfathomable and heart-breaking that the brain cant quite comprehend. I doubt it ever will.:Susan Swarbricks Week:I need a bedathon ndash blankets, biscuits and box set bingesWhat will it take for Johnson and his blundering cronies to get a grip on this pandemic  Every decision, every announcement, is like watching a car crash in slow motion. And there was you thinking this was a column about pancakes.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: notes-africa-hole-one-hole-head
story: Primus, our prize turkey, was also having a problem with holes, in his case the shallow one his we insisted on scratching out beneath shady cassava leaves. There, in secret, she laid her eggs then went AWOL. Being a responsible father, he was often found sitting on the eggs, these frequent paternal episodes disrupting his routine and causing serious wattle engorgement. After the third failed hatching, the Czar of All Livestock decided the limit had been reached, and Primusrsquos new we is a strong young bird with a sense of social and maternal responsibility.Our most important hole is several hundred metres long, two metres deep, and full of water moving apace. Weeks of rain and the building of a major tarred road to the West Nile, a few hundred metres from our land, meant saturated and damaged fields, and the erosion of our buildingsrsquo foundations.Fortunately, the Madi and French construction companyrsquos engineers agreed with Anne Mariersquos proposed remedy and within three days we felt saved ndash the compound dried out, the fields are recovering, and our staff pit latrine has emptied of water for the first time since last Easter.At the Ngwenya iron ore mine in Swaziland we have a choice of holes to explore on our visits, millions of tons having been gouged out in the s and sent to Japan. The mine has been worked for some , years but as a source of iron only from about AD. The archaeologists, including John Masson from Scotland, have shown it was originally a source of red ochre, widely used for ritual purposes and for Bushman rock art.Only a few years ago, the highly-educated we of one of my oldest friends had to succumb to ochre smearing before the traditional wedding ceremony could be completed. Specular haematite was mined there too, its glittering quality impressive even now ndash how much more so on the limbs and head of a shaman prowling through a village in the night The smallest hole medically was caused by a long metal meat skewer driven through a young teenagerrsquos forehead after horseplay with her younger brother. She walked into casualty at Good Shepherd, calm as you like. Fortunately, it was exactly in the midline and had avoided the brain tissue itself on each side, as well as major arteries and venous sinuses.We did not have scans in those days, let alone neurosurgeons ndashonly detailed anatomy books. Under anaesthetic and using our Canadian dentistrsquos high-speed drill, the entry hole was enlarged. Diathermy to coagulate any blood vessels was applied directly to the skewer as it was withdrawn, millilmetre by fraught millimetre. Most of us in theatre probably stopped breathing before it finally was freed. She walked out with a smile several days later whereas the poor brother, sjambokked all over his back and limbs by his dad, was not able to move for some time.The most fiendishly designed hole I encountered was on the Old Course at St Andrews. My elder brother, Alan, a doctor in Canada, suggested we drive through very early from Stirling to seethere was a space available on the rota for two natives amid the throngs of Americans.We were in luck. It was an emotional moment for both of us, stepping on to that fabled tee, holy ground in our minds, golfrsquos ghosts and legends everywhere around. The euphoria would have continued all day until my drive disappeared on the fth fairway. Do they still have pot bunkers in the st century  There was barely room to swing a sand wedge in this deep devilrsquos cavity. Alan had a smirk on his face ndash he was one hole down.My instinct was to swing the sand wedge then throw the ball out onto the fairway. Reality dawned ndash you donrsquot mess with older brothers. ldquoIrsquom declaring it unplayable, Alan. Two stroke penalty and one clubnot nearer the hole.ldquoDamn! I was going to enjoy watching you down there for the next  minutes.Dr David Vost studied medicine at Glasgow University and works at a hospital in Swaziland. He and his family live on a farm in Northern Uganda. davidvostsz@gmail

story: Figures from the Scottish Retail Consortium show that in the fourth quarter of , the Scottish vacancy rate increased .% to .%.At .% higher than , this means Scotland has the fth highest prevent these vacant units lying empty for two, three, four years or more.ldquoLooking further out, the increase in availability of space will provide opportunities for new businesses, however we must prepare ourselves for the picture to get worse before it gets better.It comes after Scotlandrsquos Finance Secretary announced her Budget plans yesterday.Outlining her draft spending plans in the Scottish Parliament on Thursday, Kate Forbes said the pandemic had ldquoshaken our society and economy to their core.Describing Brexit as a ldquowrecking ball, she added: ldquoTodayrsquos Budget will as well as tracking a course over the coming year to build a fairer, stronger and greener country.She announced pound. billion of support for jobs and skills and pound billion for health, as well asa further pound million for tackling coronavirus ndash including funding for the vaccination and test and trace programmes.Ms Forbes said the strategic framework business fund, which provides grants based on restrictions put on businesses, will continue beyond this financial year, provided funding is forthcoming from the UK Government.Grants being paid to businesses in February will also be paid at the maximum level, regardless of the level of restrictions on firms, she said.Councils will also see an increase in their finances, with discretionary funding doubling to pound million and a further pound million to compensate for a loss of income due to the pandemic.:Scottish Budget Recap: Kate Forbes delivers SNPs spending plansAll Scottish taxpayers will pay slightly less this year than last, Ms Forbes added, as the tax band system will remain unchanged.The starter, basic and higher bands of tax will all rise by inflation, with the top rate frozen at pound,.Non-domestic rates relief for some businesses will be extended for three months, until more clarity is offered from the UK Government.Ms Forbes said businesses in the retail, hospitality and leisure sectors will continue to pay nothing while other firms will see their rates fall.She also said a national infrastructure plan for Scotland which aims to support , jobs across the country will be announced next title: thank-goodness-blustering-boris---week-john-swinney
story: Dinnae think Irsquom not serious. Itrsquos allowed us to get away with all sorts. What about Her Greatnessrsquos statement about turning down the offer of army help to sort out the piled-up vaccine  ldquoWe do not want to put undue burden on the army when we donrsquot think we necessarily need them.Undue burden  We all know theyrsquore doing little  at the moment except marching drill in muddy boots or checking out Michelle Keegan in Our Girl.And look how we managed to sell the headlines of the pound million of funding to help support the student people of Scotland ndash without so much as a referral to me throwing them under a bus back in October.But as far as my work as Education Secretary goes, I would like to reassure your readers that I can truly empathise with the children people of Scotland.Indeed, I often feel like a wee boy, given the times Irsquove had to stick three jotters down my trousers before facing the EIS to explain, for example, the SQA fiasco.Her Unalloyed Greatness has often told me to sit in the corner and wear the duncersquos cap.And didnrsquot I once take a right spanking from the BBCrsquos Gary Robertson the time I refused to answer his question about start-up costs for an independent Scotland ndash  times So letrsquos celebrate a week in which we werenrsquot even quizzed on our wonderfully nebulous position on quarantining, getting away with saying we would be going ldquoat least as far as the UK Government.Now, you know that what this really means is we like to take the Westminster position and add a wee bit of extra juice, just for the independence spin-off sothe UK Government suggests an anorak and thick socks strategy, metaphorically speaking, ken, in the battle to stop Covid , wersquoll add a semmit. Very possibly a balaclava.But I wonrsquot avoid the tough questions.If yoursquore asking me why we didnrsquot call for quarantine hotels to be introduced, as they had in Australia, a year ago, let me make my position very clear. These Antipodeans didnrsquot even give Andy Murray, one of the special people of Scotland, the extra time to make the Australian Open, so I wonrsquot even begin to answer that question.What I will say is I promise to remain as doggedly indeterminate as always, to continue using pointless phrases such as ldquoI want to take the politics out of my decisions.Thank goodness for blustering Boris, otherwise some may have said ldquoThatrsquos easy, John. Take yourself out of politics and go back to working in a bank.As imagined by Brian Beacom

title: toe-tipping-visit-stockholm-syndrome
story: The Daily MailHenry Deedes watched the Prime Ministerrsquos trip over the Border on Thursday and said his ventures into Scotland were always lsquotoe tippersrsquo.ldquoBoris is as welcome here as Donald Trump landing a gold helicopter in the middle of Celtic Park, he said. ldquoBorisrsquos main purpose was to drum up support for the Union, currently draining faster than a leaky washing machine hose.He said, when askedhis visit was really necessary given current restrictions, the PM was a little overenthusiastic about meeting frontline workers. ldquoIt was as though he was trying to convince the hostess of a dreary cocktail party what a fabulous time he was having, he said.ldquoTalk quickly turned toward Scottish independence. A slight wince. Crsquomon Boris, you knew this was coming, he added. ldquoHe insisted holding another referendum wasnrsquot the right thing to do at this moment. Besides, the Scots had just had one. Next!The Ross Clark said pharmaceutical companies were often damned for selling drugs we donrsquot need but AstraZeneca did not deserve the attacks that had been launched on it this week by the EU.ldquoThe company has been charged with failing to deliver supplies of its Covid- vaccine on time, and of favouring the NHS over EU healthcare systems in what the EU calls ldquovaccine nationalism, he said. ldquoOn Wednesday, the EU threatened legal action unless the company erted  million doses of the vaccine from the UK to the EU, and on Thursday it raided the companyrsquos factory in Belgium.He said it was an outrageous and unfair attack. ldquoIt isnrsquot EU commissioners - still less social justice warriors - who are going to get us out of this crisis, he said. ldquoThe real heroes of the hour are the scientists and technicians who have been beavering away in the laboratories over the past  months.Emma Brockes asked how we were really doing, barely leaving home, home schooling and not seeing family for nearly a year.ldquoWe are unmoored from all but a handful of close friends, she said. ldquoIf it is fine ndash and it is largely fine, or at least it is this week ndash I also wondersome social muscle has atrophied and we have become weird.She said the virus was holding us hostage and many were suffering from Stockholm syndrome, unwilling to raise from the sofa or take part in Zoom calls with friends.ldquoIrsquom assuming it wonrsquot last, this resentment and recoil, although who knows how profoundly our habits have changed , she said. ldquo[After bumping into a friend Irsquom reminded of the fun of talking to others] then almost immediately ndash thinking how long before I can get out of it and go home

story: However Scottish Labours current race for its newest leader is striking a decidedly dferent tone.Monica Lennon, MSP for Central Scotland and Anas Sarwar, Glasgow MSP, have both set out their stalls and are, so far, conducting civilised campaigns to win the votes of members.With ballots opening on February  the contest looks likely to heat up a notch or two in the weeks ahead, before a decision is made at the end of the month.Before it gets messy, HANNAH RODGER asked both candidates for their views on the other, with some surprising responses.Anas on MonicaWhat is Monicas best quality "I donrsquot consider Monica to be an opponent. Monica is a formidable campaigner, as we have seen in her work to tackle period poverty in Scotland."And her biggest flaw "The great thing about this election is that wersquore both running positive campaigns and the only flaws wersquore focused on is our real oppositionrsquos flaws ndash the SNPrsquos obsession with ision and the Toriesrsquo disastrous running of the country."What do you think is her biggest political achievement so far "Monicarsquos period poverty campaign not only made a positive dference for all people in Scotland who menstruate, but sent a message to countries around the world about how to tackle inequalities.":Scottish Labour hopeful Anas Sarwar would reach out to Richard Leonard to try and unite partyAside from politics, what hobbies do you think, or know, Monica has "I know Monica loves walks with her family and their beautul dog, Cuillin. The jobs we do can be very stressful at times and dficult for our families, so itrsquos important we all have a way to switch off from the world and relax. I also recently learnt that she has a campervan, so Irsquom sure she canrsquot wait for Covid to be over."If Monica was an animal, what animal would she be and why "Oh, thatrsquos a dangerous question! I wouldnrsquot like to compare Monica to any animal, butforced to... perhaps a bee because she helps keep everything going, or maybe a dolphin "If you were not running for leader, would you vote for Monica "Yes, I think Monica has made a huge contribution to public le as an MSP and has a big role to play in our partyrsquos future whatever happens in this election."If you went for dinner with Monica, do you think she would have good table manners "Yes, absolutely. I donrsquot know about Cuillin though, I imagine he is very excitable!"What three words would best describe Monica "Energetic, determined, compassionate."If Monica was not a politician, what do you think her job would be "Like me, Monica is motivated by public service. If she wasnrsquot a politician I think she would be in town planning, a job I know she loved before becoming an MSP, helping to shape and design our communities."Do you think she would make a good leader for Scottish Labour "I hope members feel they are choosing between two people who would both be good leaders of our party. When this internal contest is over, we must all work together on rebuilding Scottish Labour so that we can rebuild Scotland."Monica on AnasWhat is Anass best quality "Anas is determined and committed. Anas has many good qualities, Irsquom more interested in the flawed record of other political parties and advancing Scottish Labours vision."What do you think is his biggest political achievement so far "Anas raised the tragic case of Milly Main who died after contracting an infection at Glasgows Queen Elizabeth University Hospital. He supported Millys mother Kimberly Darroch in her desperate search for answers, and other families, and continues to do so.":Monica Lennon says her top priority will be tackling child povertyshe wins Scottish Labour leadershipAside from politics, what hobbies do you think, or know, Anas has "I think hersquos a keen championship football manager ndash certainly in the online world, but not so sure what hersquos like on the pitch! It will be clear in the weeks ahead that we donrsquot agree on everything, however, we both want what is best for Scottish Labour and Scotland as a whole."

title: textiles-go-back-future-new-inspiration
story: The process of producing the cloth is the same as itrsquos always been the clatter of the looms as the pattern takes shape, the nimble fingers of the weaver, eyes fixed on the spinning threads, the cogs, chains and shuttles.But while the task at hand is rooted in the past, the tartans which roll from the Prickly Thistle mill are firmly in the present bespoke and modern designs often created as the result of collaborations with clients from around the world, in vibrant colours and complex patterns.Itrsquos tartan ndash made at the regionrsquos only tartan textile mill - but not as Highland clans of the past might recognise it.And, itrsquos being suggested, the millrsquos lsquorebel tartanrsquo is an example of what can be achieved when the creators and designers of today turn to the past for inspiration.A new initiative, Heritage as a Creative Future, has been launched to encourage interaction between the Highland and Islandsrsquo creative industries and the arearsquos heritage ndash from the old as time natural landscape to traditional skills, museum objects, peoplersquos stories and company archives.The online series of webinars, hosted by Highlands creative economy support organisation XpoNorth, also examines how museums and heritage organisations can in turn become archives of fashion products, and inspire new works.According to leading design anthropologist, Dr Aude Le Guennec, Assistant Professor at the School of Textiles and Design, Heriot-Watt University, the Prickly Thistle example shows how the rich heritage of Highland skills and textiles can be given a modern twist to meet consumersrsquo demands for products which tell a story of traditions, landscape and history.She says there are many potential areas of inspiration to ignite the creative spark.ldquoFrom creative industries perspective, it could be anything around, it could be the landscape, history, objects in museums or collections and how they use that to create dferent products and tell a story.ldquoOne colleague at Heriot-Watt is doing a project where he is looking at sounds which are part of our heritage and transforming sound waves to textiles.ldquoItrsquos not about going to a gallery, looking at something and reproducing it. Itrsquos looking at the landscape and thinking of how to integrate it or using an old technique to produce a product that meets the expectations of todayrsquos customers, she adds.ldquoItrsquos using an unexpected part of heritage in a dferent way to tell stories.The seminar organisers have pointed to recent work by Edinburgh-based Craft Design House, which has drawn inspiration from the le of Arctic adventurer, botanist and writer Isobel Wylie Hutchison to create a collection of wearable, accessories and homeware.While some designers, such as Fair Isle knitwear specialist Mati Ventrillon, have already taken inspiration from museum collections of traditional designs and patterns of the past to create new, highly desirable fashion items for new markets.Others have fused traditional Highland products in innovative ways to ignite the interest of modern consumers - such as a range of Harris Tweed imbued with the scent of whisky, the result of a project involving Harris Tweed Hebrides, Johnnie Walker Black Label and textile experts at Heriot-Watt University.Clare Campbell of Prickly Thistle says while her tartan products are soaked in Highland heritage, they are created with modern customersrsquo demands for sustainability, heritage and style in mind.ldquoWersquore disrupting the way tartan is produced on a number of levels, she adds. ldquoWe are using cast iron looms that give us more creative freedom, are highly sustainable and create more jobs.ldquoWersquore disrupting the clan system of tartan design and working collaboratively with people around the world.ldquoWe make kilts, but we are also pushing forward towards creating modern styles of highland dress and new designs that have zero waste.ldquoConsumers now realise that mass consumerism is killing everything, and theyrsquore looking for products that are more than fast fashion.Meanwhile in Orkney, textile designer Kirsteen Stewartrsquos window showcases the arearsquos natural heritage, with dramatic open skies, rugged coastlines and the power of the sea inspiring her range of textiles.While most become clothes or accessories, she has found an innovative use for some fabric ndash as a vibrant splash of colour and shape on a surfboard.She has also delved into the archives of Orkney jewellery designer Sheila Fleet for a collaborative collection of scarves and is working with other local creatives using natural heritage and skills as inspiration for prints inspired by the underwater landscape of Scapa Flow Bay and a corset made from rope.ldquoOur lestyles are changing, and people want to buy products with an authentic story behind them, she says.She has plans to develop the surfboard and swimwear, both items typically associated with tropical designs but which she says could instead be decorated with the patterns inspired by Orkney plants, sunsets or underwater seascapes.Iain Hamilton, Head of Creative Industries at Highlands and Islands Enterprise, and co-founder of XpoNorth, says: ldquoProvenance and authenticity is a big selling point at the moment.ldquoPeople want to buy things that are more than just an immediate product they want something that has really some meaning behind it.He suggests Highland and Islands producers might look to Scandinavian countries, where traditions and heritage have inspired distinctive lsquoScandic stylersquo products and influenced literature and film.ldquoThe Highlands can have a similar impact ndash therersquos a feeling and a look that people identy with.ldquoItrsquos not about recreating the past, he adds. ldquoItrsquos about how to use the things form the past to create something new, but which tells you a story.The online seminars, which run until April, are available at www.exponorth.

title: gorbals-can-inspire-scotlands-town-centres-future
story: Densely populated, roamed by razor gangs and gripped by appalling poverty, the Gorbals became synonymous with everything that was wrong with Scottish housing while its hard done by residents were admired for their strong community bonds, spirit and compassion.Now, in a remarkable turnaround that would no doubt have tenants of the past reeling, the Gorbals is being held up as a prime example of the neighbourhood of the future.According to Craig McLaren, Director of Scotland, Ireland and English Regions at the Royal Town Planning Institute , the arearsquos regeneration has created the kind of ldquo-minute neighbourhood ndash where almost all of whatrsquos required by its residents can be reached within a short walk or cycle - that could become a blueprint for the post-Covid- landscape.:High-rise in Glasgows Gorbals to be demolished on SundayThe organisation is now calling for Scottish Government funding to help communities across Scotland lay down plans for their own neighbourhoods of the future.ldquoThe Gorbals has high quality housing, quite high density and a lot of it built on ideas of the past, he says.ldquoThere is a library, a community centre, supermarket and a range of other shops and it has green space. Itrsquos well designed. There are links to public transport so people who need to go outside the area for other services can get to the city centre easily, by walking or by bus.ldquoRegeneration was reusing land that had been used before, not digging up greenfield sites.ldquoIt was developed through a masterplan put in place that set out how to develop it over a long period, so it was phased and with the public and private sectors working together.Last September the First Ministerrsquos Programme for Government pledged poundm investment over five years to support active travel and poundm to support investment in communities including lsquo-minute neighbourhoodsrsquo.Originally developed in Portland, Oregon, and intended to boost prosperity, health, equality and educational outcomes, -minute neighbourhoods are carefully planned to give residents with almost everything they need for day to day living on their doorstep, undoing the need for a car.The idea has been adopted in Paris, where authorities are championing a rsquo-minute cityrsquo, and Melbourne in Australia where it is embedded in the cityrsquos long-term planning strategy.Momentum here has grown in the wake of Covid- pandemic lockdowns, which have left city centres deserted and highlighted the benefits of communities with services alongside homes, where residents can access public green space, walk or cycle instead of using cars, and with good digital connectivity to enable working from home or at local digital hubs.The idea harks back to generations past before key services such as libraries, GP surgeries, Post Offices and shops were centralised in sometimes hard to reach locations, retail parks and out of town developments.Supporters say a knock-on impact of -minute neighbourhoods would be less congestion in city centres, with urban office space potentially converted into affordable housing and an expansion of leisure facilities.The high-rise flats were destroyed in The RTPI Scotland is now calling on the Scottish Government to release funds so communities can work with the public and private sector to develop their own Local Place Plans and -minute neighbourhoods.It is also highlighting the need for a greater role for professional planners, including investment in planning jobs and ato days when town planners were highly influential with influence on local authoritiesrsquo asset management and spending.According to Mr McLaren, carefully planned -minute neighbourhoods could bring a wide range of benefits.ldquoIn terms of trying to reach zero carbon targets, people will not need to travel as much, he says. ldquoTherersquod be health benefits for people because people can access green spaces. Covid- has shown how people have valued having local amenities and green spaces around them.:A walking tour of Glasgows transformed Laurieston districtRedesigning neighbourhoods around the -minute model could help address inequality in how services, amenities and work can be accessed by the third of Scottish households who do not own a car, a figure which increases to half in deprived areas.It would also align with active travel and public transport strategies, helping to lower car use and boost demand for buses while bringing health benefits of more walking and cycling.Reduced need for roads and car parking would then open up green areas for play, community use and growing food.An important element of creating -minute neighbourhoods is ensuring local communities are empowered to design the places in which they live, adds Mr McLaren.ldquoThe way people engage with planning tends to be through objections to a planning application. We want to flip that so people tell us what they want rather than what they donrsquot want.RITP Scotland has called for investment in planning departments, which have faced the largest cuts in local government expenditure since   and seen % staffing cuts.ldquoWe currently have a fairly opportunist and short-term uncoordinated approach to how we plan things. Planning is not used to full effect, he adds.ldquoWe do need to change the way we live our lives and the way our places feel and look. We need to start thinking to longer term and move away from very opportunistic ways of developing our towns and cities.Stuart Hay, Director, Living Streets Scotland says the disruption to work and travel brought by Covid- is a ldquoonce in a generation opportunity to tackle a host of transport-based societal problems, including carbon emissions, air pollution, inactivity-related diseases, traffic accidents and weak community connections.He adds: ldquoWe need to get more people walking their short everyday journeyswersquore to tackle the climate emergency, boost our local economies and become healthier. This means getting the basics right and improving infrastructure.ldquoBy creating rsquo-minute neighbourhoodsrsquo, which build facilities close to where people live and work, we can make walking a more pleasant and convenient option for many more people.ldquoIf you plan for cars - you get traffic and emissions. Butyou plan for people and places ndash you get more walking and great places to live.Sustainable transport charity Sustrans also supports the idea of -minute neighbourhoods.Daisy Narayanan, Director of Urbanism, says: ldquoCities and towns should be places that connect us to each other and the things we need, and should be places where everyone can thrive without being locked into car dependency.ldquoThe best way to do this is to ensure that it is easy for people to meet most of their everyday needs in their local area.ldquoNeighbourhoods are defined by the communities who live there, and each will have unique expectations of the services and facilities they need.ldquoHowever, the coronavirus pandemic, and the subsequent lockdowns that have been put in place across the country, highlight how vital it is for people to be able to live locally, and to be able to access shops, health centres and schools by using safe and physically distanced modes of transport such as walking and cycling.ldquoToo many neighbourhoods have been planned around car travel at the expense of providing the local jobs and services that a community needs to thrive. It is important that we learn from what we are experiencing now to shape our towns and cities of the future.

title: iain-macwhirter-vaccine-nationalism-shows-not-together
story: In fact, the very reverse has been the case, as nations have rediscovered their primary role in protecting their own people first. Borders are back. The globalisation trend of the last half century is being thrown into reverse as travel is banned indefinitely and international supply chains collapse. When Donald Trump closed the borders to EU travellers back in March he was attacked for being xenophobic, even racist. Now everyonersquos shutting borders. Nationalism is on the march: from Scotland to New Zealand.Vaccine nationalism has now ripped through Europe. Brussels has resorted to the modern equivalent of gunboat diplomacy: issuing threats, raiding factories, seeking to halt the movement of vaccines, even ldquomistakenly trying to create a hard border in Ireland. It seems that the spirit of Donald Trump lives on in Brussels."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "EU vaccine row: Gove confident programme will continue as planned","description": "EU vaccine row: Gove confident programme will continue as planned","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media GpLcStQE poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests GpLcStQE.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": :Coronavirus: Oxford-AstraZeneca Covid vaccine approved for use in UKThe target is the British-Swedish company AstraZeneca, but the United Kingdom is also in the frame, accused of a ldquome first approach and, by extension, of hoarding of supplies of the precious vaccines. Nicola Sturgeon has also got in the blame game, apparently claiming UK responsibility for the delays in the Scottish vaccine programme.Opposition parties claim it is rather a result of her inefficiency.Brussels, meanwhile, is trying to strong arm AstraZeneca into redirecting some of its UK vaccine supply to Europe. It is also threatening to block exports of the Pfizer vaccine from Europe.This would be an extraordinary lapse into vaccine protectionism. It would arguably be illegal under EU laws on state intervention and free movement. But when lives are at stake, who cares about laws.The situation in Europe is undoubtedly dire. Countries like Spain and Portugal, which are struggling to cope with a menacing third wave of Covid, have been forced to cancel immunisation programmes. Old people could die as a result of not getting their jags on time.The European press is furious and has accused Brussels of a catastrophic failure to meet its obligations.Brussels had insisted on negotiating for vaccines collectively for all countries above the heads of inidual nation states.This was to prevent a recurrence of the chaotic border closures last April, and the unedying sight of EU countries squabbling over the delivery of PPE masks and gowns. It didnrsquot want smaller countries to be left behind, either. Unfortunately, the whole of the EU has now found itself in the vaccine slow lane.Britain got ahead of the curve, for once.In March, long before it was even known whether a vaccine against Covid- was possible, the UK Government decided to invest massively in the development of what it regarded as the most likely candidates.It pumped money into the Oxford research and, more importantly, into AstraZenecarsquos manufacturing supply chain. The UK Vaccine Taskforce recruited , volunteers to test future vaccines. This meant thatand when new ones emerged they could receive regulatory approval very quickly.The UK Government signed contracts with AstraZeneca for  million doses three months before Brussels.:Covid vaccine Scotland: How many jags in my area The EU held out for a lower cost and got caught in bureaucratic delays trying to negotiate for all  nations in the Union. The EU had still not authorised the AstraZeneca vaccine for use last week, even as it was accusing the firm ndash which makes no profit from the vaccine ndash of selling to the highest bidder.All hell broke loose on January  when AstraZeneca told Brussels that because of problems in its Belgian plant, it could only supply one-quarter of the  million odd doses it had agreed to deliver by March.The company insists that it had entered into what is called a ldquobest effort agreement, and that it gave no cast-iron commitment to deliver come what may.The UK Government has sought to keep out of the row. There has been some injudicious crowing from Brexiters like Nigel Farage. But Boris Johnson has tried to sound magnanimous, offering to help out in the EU once its UK order has been fulfilled.But no way is he agreeing to give up British vaccines ordered and paid for. If he did, the immunisation schedule would be delayed here and people in the UK might die.Itrsquos the age-old question of altruism: are you willing to risk the lives of British people in order to save lives in other countries As in wartime, the first responsibility of any government in a national crisis is always going to be the welfare of its own people. This is a legal responsibility of the state, though one so obvious that it rarely needs to be stated.The sight of the richest countries on the planet squabbling over millions of vaccines is unedying, to put it mildly. Many African countries have been able only to get their hands on hundreds or less. However, the poor countries have been cautious in their condemnation.They need this to be resolved quickly so they can get sorted with vaccines under the UN-sponsored COVAX programme. The UK has pledged pound million, rather more than the EU.With the world watching there is a moral imperative for this disgraceful row to be resolved as quickly as possible.Fortunately, new vaccines seem to be arriving almost by the week, like the Valneva vaccine which is to be manufactured in Livingston. Once again, the UK pre-ordered  million doses and invested heavily in manufacturing before there was any guarantee of success.Boris Johnson made a point of visiting the plant last week to demonstrate the ldquobenefits of the Union.The question being asked in the capitals of Europe, and in Germany in particular, is why the European Union, with all its buying power, was left so flat-footed.It underlines a basic contradiction in the constitutional arrangements. It is baked into the DNA of the EU that nationalism is a curse, which in many ways it is. They talk of ldquoBritish exceptionalism and ldquoBrexit nativism asthis is a character defect.However, the problem with Brussels is precisely that it is not a nation and does not see itself as responsible to any one national community.The European Commission is not a democratic institution and cannot be held to account through a general election. It is a bureaucracy which, like all bureaucracies, puts its own protocols first.Everything has to be processed through the national governments of  member states. Nimble it is not.A delay in supply might have seemed a small price to pay for ensuring that all of Europe moved at the same pace. However, it failed to appreciate that the voters in member countries would not see it that way.In future, Europe may have to become a proper state or the nations may, to coin a phrase, take back control.

title: neil-mackays-big-read-scottish-academics-go-head-to-head-nations-ugly-legacy-slavery
story: Their explosive exchange shows just how far we have to go as a country before we truly come to terms with our past. Writer at Large Neil Mackay reportsIF evidence were needed of Scotlandrsquos bitter, unresolved legacy of slavery, then proof is to be found in the tense and at times acrimonious relationship between two of Scotlandrsquos most distinguished academics when it comes to the truth about our nationrsquos past.Sir Tom Devine is Scotlandrsquos most distinguished historian, and the man who quite literally wrote the book on the nationrsquos role in empire and slavery. Sir Geoff Palmer is Scotlandrsquos first black professor, and a champion of the Black Lives Matter movement.This week, The Herald on Sunday hosted the pair in a private online debate about Scotland, slavery and the legacy of history.Fittingly, the debate occurred on Burns Night. The legacy of Scotlandrsquos national poet is now under reassessment itself given he once considered taking up an overseer position on a slave plantation.To say the discussion was fraught is an understatement. At the heart of the two academicsrsquo dferences is the way Scotland should view Sir Henry Dundas ndash an Edinburgh aristocrat who became one of the most powerful men in the British empire during the late s. Dundas, known as ldquothe Uncrowned King of Scotland, was right-hand man to Prime Minister William Pitt.He was at the heart of the wars against revolutionary France and British expansion in India. Victorians saw him as a towering symbol of the Enlightenment.A statute of him stands in Edinburgh. However, today he is infamous for his role in slavery.In , the anti-slavery campaigner William Wilberforce put a motion before parliament calling for slavery to be abolished.Although Dundas claimed he opposed slavery, he tabled an amendment calling for ldquogradual abolition and for the slave trade to be ended ldquoby moderate measures.It wasnrsquot until , therefore, that the slave trade was eventually outlawed ndash although it took until  for a full ban on the owning of slaves to be enforced. Campaigners see Dundas as guilty of continuing one of the most dreadful crimes in world history.As a result, amid the Black Lives Matter protests last year, a plaque was erected at Dundasrsquos statue denouncing him as instrumental in preventing the abolition of slavery, and so responsible for continuing atrocities across the Caribbean.Palmer played a central role in ensuring the plaque went up. Devine takes issue not only with how Dundasrsquos role in the continuation of slavery is perceived, but also with the way in which the plaque was erected. Their dferences strike right at the heart of how Scotland deals with its legacy of slavery.Scottish amnesiaWhat is clear, though, is that both men hold slavery in utter contempt and detest modern racism. Nevertheless, their dispute over the interpretation of the past is rancorous.Devine begins by noting that Scotland has only recently started coming to terms with its history of slavery. The study of ldquoslavery and Scotland as a subject ldquowas only really born about  years ago whereas England has been debating the issue since the post-war period.ldquoTo some extent, the passions in the south have already been exhausted whereas in Scotland so much of this material is new and challenging, he says.Over the last decade or so, it has become clear, says Devine, ldquothat Scotland was implicated deeply in the reality and the legacy of slavery hellip Every nook and cranny of Scottish le had direct or indirect connections to slave-based economies across the Atlantic in the th century.He adds: ldquoDespite the fact that Scotland had collective amnesia over this issue for centuries hellip Scotland was actually more dependent on these slave-based economic systems than England. Much of Scotlandrsquos wealth and industrial revolution was dependent on slavery. Palmer says that when he has given lectures around the country many people have been completely unaware of Scotlandrsquos role in slavery."The consistent response from the audience has been lsquowhy hasnrsquot anyone told us this before rsquo. He pointedly adds that people have walked past the Dundas statue for generations, and the many landmarks in Glasgow linked to slavery, and ldquothey hadnrsquot a clue.Neither Palmer nor Devine want statues of men like Dundas taken down ndash both see them as important historical artefacts, which teach us about the past.However, when Palmer became involved in moves to erect a plaque at the Dundas statue, he was taken aback by claims that the man was a ldquogradual abolitionist. He denounces such statements as ldquohumbug and says ldquoDundas was guilty of villainy and rotten to the core.Forces of historyWhere the pair dfer, says Devine, relates to ldquothe controversy over the Dundas [statue] and the role of Henry Dundas, and whether or not he prolonged the slave trade led to many thousands of other African people being transported across the Atlantic.:Its time for our children to learn the truth about Scotlands role in slave tradeDevine notes he finds it ironic that he is ldquodefending ndash at least on a specic issue ndash this long dead man, becauseyou look at his role in history, and leave aside slavery, Dundas was an autocrat, unrelentingly opposed to political reform hellip an utter reactionary, and as far as I can tell not a very pleasant human being.However, Devine says that as a historian he must judge historical figures on ldquoevidence, much of it inevitably ambiguous hellip without fear or favour or whether I canrsquot stand the man or not. Devine says that studying the evidence leads him to the opinion that ldquothe jury is still out on [Dundasrsquos] personal role hellipPersonally, Irsquove not come across what Irsquod describe as entirely convincing evidence to convict [Dundas] one way or another of postponing or trying to postpone the end of the slave trade.Devine adds that ldquoevenDundas had never existed as an inidual or high-ranking politician, slavery would not have been abolished in the s because ldquoforces political, economic and military were so potent that there was no way a British government would want to get abolition over the line.Among those key forces were Britainrsquos war with France, the fact that the Caribbean was central to the economy of Empire, and slave rebellions in the French colony Saint-Domingue ndash now Haiti. Britain, Devine says, ldquowas fighting in a titanic struggle with France, not only for its very existence but the future control of Empire across the Atlantic.Slave rebellions ldquosent tremors right through the whole of the British Caribbean and the corridors of power in Westminster ndash the feeling was thatthe British gave an inch too quickly it might trigger the same kind of horror in the British Caribbean islands.The House of Lords, ldquowhich had to agree to abolition, was constantly and adamantly opposed hellip as was the King [George III] who had to sign any legislation off.Palmer questions Devinersquos position and produces a statement included in the book Recovering Scotlandrsquos Slavery Past, edited by Devine and published in . It says that Dundasrsquos ldquoparliamentary intervention hellip arguing for gradual abolition hellip effectively killed off reform for a generation.What has changed Devinersquos opinion of Dundas between  and today, Palmer wants to know.Devine admits that his view of Dundas has changed. ldquoThe point about my discipline is that it moves on hellip I believed that in , I no longer believe it because I look at the totality of the period hellip My position has moved from an inidual critique hellip to seeing the thing in terms of these very potent historical developments and forces which ensured [abolition] couldnrsquot happen.ldquoTom, Palmer pointedly says, ldquohas changed his mind. Palmer says as a scientist he would never come to ldquoconclusions without evidence.Slaveryrsquos friendDUNDAS, Palmer says, ldquogave money which facilitated the debt that some of these slavers had gone into hellip notorious slavers who didnrsquot want abolition. He points to James Baillie, a notorious Scottish slaver in the West Indies, descended from William Wallace, as one of those Dundas supported.How history views Dundas, says Palmer, is critical ldquoin terms of the general public. He worries that those who describe Dundas as a ldquogradual abolitionist pave the way for him eventually becoming ldquoan abolitionist in the public mind. Palmer says he was quite clearly a supporter of slavery.:Henry Dundas - Controversial legacy of Scotlands most powerful manPalmer goes on to point out that in a  letter, Dundas speaks of opposing abolition. Dundas also, Palmer says, facilitated that ldquoblack slaves should be enlisted into the British army to fight the French, and ordered action against fugitive slaves in Jamaica.ldquoThatrsquos gradual abolition  Palmer asks.Palmer says that in the Caribbean part of Dundasrsquos strategy was ldquobringing in young slaves hellip so that in the end you could be self-producing your own slaves. He wonrsquot countenance any suggestion that Dundas was not guilty of continuing the slave trade.Any claims by Dundas at the time that he was a gradualist, says Palmer, simply chime with other misleading statements by similar politicians in the late s, who were all guilty of ldquothis awful hypocrisy hellip saying one thing and doing the other. He adds: ldquoDundasrsquos gradualism is like gradual murder.Dundas, Palmer goes on, ldquowanted to develop slave plantations in Jamaica. When the word ldquogradual is used in connection with Dundas, Palmer says, we should take it to mean that he was ldquorefusing to act until a thousand favourable circumstances united ndash that really means never hellip he was playing the game hellip he was involved in delaying abolition.Palmer adds it is curious that when Dundas was impeached in , the ldquoslave trade was abolished in .Angry exchangesDEVINE responds by saying: ldquoGeoff presents [Dundas] as a kind of superman, a titan who single-handedly managed to produce this extraordinary historical result of postponing abolition.The only reason Dundas was able to achieve this end wasnrsquot because of personal skills hellip [but] because the forces of history, unfortunately for a period, were in favour of people like the postponers ndash aka him ndash or people who were root and branch opposed to abolition hellip We must move from the role, for good or ill ndash probably for ill ndash of one inidual and see this as an international process, based especially on war, which confounded the abolitionists until the early-th century.At this stage of the debate, the conversation degenerates into the two men talking over each other and general bickering.ldquoI just think he was irrelevant, says Devine. ldquoHe was the minister of war and the home secretary, Palmer responds.He was just ldquoone influential man, Devine adds. ldquoAre you saying the lsquoUncrowned King of Scotlandrsquo was the stooge of a whole lot of other people hellip that hersquod no power  Palmer asks.The legacyTHE Herald on Sunday brings the debate to order and moves on to asking both men why the legacy of Dundas matters today. ldquoWersquove a situation of  national pride, says Palmer.Thatrsquos ldquoa deception, he adds. When an Edinburgh City Council committee ndash on which Palmer sat ndash debated putting up the plaque at the Dundas statue, claims were made that Dundas was an abolitionist, Palmer says. ldquoThe public needs clarication on that, he adds.Devine disagrees with ldquothe way, and the outcome of the way, the plaque was revised. He says the issue should have been debated with ldquodispassionate impartiality.He adds: ldquoWhatrsquos said on that plaque needs to combine, in addition to the condemnation of Dundas hellip the context of the time which allowed the postponement of abolition to take place hellip This is such a fundamental part of our history hellip it must be debated.He questions why no ldquotrained historian was part of the discussion around the Dundas statue. ldquoEdinburgh council should hang its head in shame, Devine says.He cites a similar discussion ongoing in Toronto about the city possibly renaming its Dundas Street, which he sees as the right process to follow. There have been public discussions, and the city will present options to ranging from scraping the street name to doing nothing.Devine says Edinburgh acted ldquoin a moment of panic. The Edinburgh judgment was made by a ldquokangaroo court, he says ndash the ruling was a ldquodiktat.ldquoI donrsquot want Dundas forgiven or applauded ndash what I want is for the historical record to be taken into account, he says. Devine adds that by  ldquothe number of people in Scotland who would have supported abolition would have been very small indeed.He says it took the majority of Scottish people a long time to come to opposition ldquoas they realised the extent to which the ramparts of their economic system depended on [slaveryrsquos] wickedness.Palmer adds: ldquoThe majority is not always right ndash at one time the majority thought the Earth was flat.The conversation starts to get fractious again. Palmer says Devinersquos complaint about no historian on the Dundas  is ldquolike saying ldquoShakespeare didnrsquot do a course in playwriting so what does he know rsquo.Palmer says people have dismissed his comments on black history because of his background as a scientist rather than an historian, adding: ldquoThatrsquos dangerous as what itrsquos saying is that my view of history isnrsquot acceptable.He raises the fact that Dundasrsquos statue stood for nearly  years ldquoand that was perfectly okay to historians ndash they didnrsquot complain about it hellip they had  years to write about it in detail hellip they didnrsquot.Palmer adds: ldquoThe council did what it thought was right and as far as the narrative on the plaque, I agree with it ndash and as far as Irsquom concerned thatrsquos it.Palmer says amending the plaquersquos text would be ldquolike saying Hitler isnrsquot responsible because he was just one man and had lots of other people around him.On claims that there is new evidence to consider about Dundas, Palmer adds: ldquoI canrsquot see the new evidence, there isnrsquot any.After another spat, the conversation calms down and debate resumes. Devine says: ldquoIrsquom totally committed to the racial equality agenda, itrsquos extraordinary itrsquos taken so long to reach this point [but]we donrsquot get this right in terms of the reckoning with the past it will continue to be an open sore and there wonrsquot be any closure.Palmer sees a continuum between men like Dundas, the actions and words of politicians like Enoch Powell in the th century, and white supremacy today, which resulted in deaths like that of George Floyd. ldquoWe cannot change the past, but we can change the consequences of the past ndash such as racism ndash for the better, he adds.With the debate becoming bogged down, Devine says he is unlikely to speak out again on such issues.He believes discussion has ldquobeen hijacked by activists, controversialists and polemicists hellip [who] will withstand the cold logic of any conclusion you present. Yoursquove lost hellip before you begin hellip I think Irsquom hitting my head against a brick wall and itrsquos becoming increasingly painful.Palmer responds: ldquoYou can write what you think is true, nobody can stop you writing, the point is that now people are being much more critical.The futureDESPITE the acrimony, the debate begins to close on a point of agreement. Both Devine and Palmer say the key to understanding the past ndash and therefore building a better future ndash is education. ldquoThe Scottish people werenrsquot informed, says Palmer. ldquoThere were misconceptions like the Scots abolished slavery.Devine adds: ldquoAs far as the future is concerned, the only long-term way around this in terms of understanding [is] hellip it must be at the heart of the school curriculum. The ldquohorrors of racism in the st century ldquoshould also loom large ndash the past doesnrsquot change, history changes.Just as the conversation is about to wind down, the pair rev up again for another tetchy exchange ndash and, after two hours, The Herald draws the debate to a close.Both men are passionate, well-intentioned, and care about society and fairness ndash but on the matter of one of Scotlandrsquos most controversial historical figures and his role in slavery, they will never agree.Perhaps the heat of their debate shows just how much this country has changed for the better, though. Twenty years ago, such a discussion would never have taken place.

title: trans-pacific-partnership-uk-formally-ask-join-free-trade-pact
story: International Trade Secretary Liz Truss will ask to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Trans-Pacic Partnershipin a conversation with ministers in Japan and New Zealand on Monday.:MPs accuse Boris Johnson of abandoning worlds vulnerable with foreign policy plansNegotiations are expected to start later this year, Ms Trussrsquos department said, in announcing the move on the anniversary of the UKrsquos formal departure from the EU.International Trade Secretary Liz TrussJoining the CPTPP will cut tarfs in trading with its  members, which also include Mexico, New Zealand and Vietnam.Great discussion at @wef on fixing the international trade system.As an independent trading nation, Global Britain will work with like-minded democracies to champion free and fair trade.Its time we had rules fit for the st century. ## # pic wsGPFSmdash Liz TrussJanuary , UK trade with the group last year was worth pound billion, according to the Department for International Trade.Prime Minister Boris Johnson said: ldquoOne year after our departure from the EU we are forging new partnerships that will bring enormous economic benefits for the people of Britain.ldquoApplying to be the first new country to join the CPTPP demonstrates our ambition to do business on the best terms with our friends and partners all over the world and be an enthusiastic champion of global free trade.Businesses reacted warmly to the plans, with the Federation of Small Businessessaying it would help firms ldquothrive and succeed more than ever.But shadow international trade secretary Emily Thornberry said Labour will closely scrutinise any pact and called on the Government to consult the public.ldquoLike any other trade agreement, the advantages of joining the CPTPP will have to be assessed once we see the terms on offer.ldquoAt present, Liz Truss cannot even guarantee whether we would have the right to veto Chinarsquos proposed accessionwe join the bloc first, she said.:Herald Opinion: We will always strive for balanceldquoMore generally, people will rightly ask why we have been through five years of debate in Britain over leaving a trade bloc with our closest neighbours only to rush into joining another one on the other side of the world without any meaningful public consultation at all.Ms Truss said joining the pact would ldquocreate enormous opportunities for UK businesses that simply werenrsquot there as part of the EU.Confederation of British Industry president Lord Bilimoria said: ldquoMembership of the bloc has the potential to deliver new opportunities for UK business across dferent sectors.Sue Davies, the head of consumer protection and food policy at Which , said ministers must ensure joining CPTPP ldquowill bring clear consumer benefits and does not dilute standards.ldquoIt is important that consumer interests are at the centre of government trade policy as the success of future agreements will be judged on what they deliver for millions of ordinary people in their everyday lives, not just the export opportunities they provide, she added.

title: coronavirus-teachers-given-support-deal-effects-pandemic-pupils
story: Up to  teachers employed in the last four years will be eligible for the scheme, which is a partnership between Education Scotland, the General Teaching Council for Scotlandand coaching provider KnowYouMore.Educators will be given one-on-one sessions where they will be able to discuss the personal and professional pressures of remote learning.:Coronavirus: Fewer than one in  pupils manage five hours a day learning"Covid- has placed unprecedented strain on school staff and none more so than those who have pastoral care and child protection responsibilities ensuring the emotional welfare of our children and young people as we recover from the pandemic," Education Secretary John Swinney said."The teacher support package I announced last year will complement the existing professional training and support already taking place for staff in schools across Scotland."Teachers need to be part of a supportive online community and have the space to stop and think about issues that are causing concern."Education Scotland chief executive Gayle Gorman said: "We have found that it really benefits teachers to know there is someone with a listening ear who are there for them."Our one-to-one coaching and mentoring sessions for headteachers have proved a really popular way of supporting their wellbeing and now the offer is also open to post-probation teachers, teachers new to role and those with pastoral responsibilities. I would encourage more practitioners to sign up.":Coronavirus: School staff threatened for getting vaccinationGTCS chief executive Ken Muir said: "GTCS is pleased to be working with our partners in education to deliver this important coaching to support hard-pressed teachers who are doing all they can to maintain quality learning in challenging circumstances."In addition to this coaching, GTCS itself has invested heavily in supporting the mental health and wellbeing of education professionals and will continue to do so throughout the pandemic."
